awd_titl_txt: REU Site: SURFing the Interface between Chemistry and Biology
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to The Scripps Research Institute, located in Jupiter, FL, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2014-2016. This award is supported by both the Directorates for Biological Sciences (Division of Biological Infrastructure) and Mathematical and Physical Sciences (Division of Chemistry). The Scripps Research Institute in Florida has a focus that integrates cutting edge bioscience research with the development of chemical tools to probe basic biological questions. Students can join any of six departments -- Cancer Biology, Chemistry, Infectious Diseases, Metabolism and Aging, Molecular Therapeutics, and Neuroscience -- where they will find themselves working at the interface between chemistry and biology. The REU experience will provide a diverse group of students with mentored training in scientific research at a top graduate program in the country, professional development opportunities focused around graduate school, including ethics training, and guided training in scientific presentation. These efforts will culminate in a campus-wide poster session, where the participants will present their findings and will be encouraged to present their results at a regional or national scientific meeting. Participants will be selected for participation based on their academic record, letters of reference and a statement of purpose. 

The location of The Scripps Research Institute in South Florida means it is well positioned to recruit students from several underrepresented groups. Undergraduates with an interest in science will have access to internationally renowned scientific research programs that will foster their interest in science by immersing them in project design, data collection and analysis, and presenting results.

The effectiveness of this program will be monitored by program evaluations including the BIO REU Sites common assessment tool and students are required to be tracked after the program and must respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information is available by visiting http://education.scripps.edu/undergraduate/flreu/index.html, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Karbstein at kkarbst@scripps.edu) or the program administrator (Mrs. Leach-Scampavia at leach@scripps.edu).

Intellectual Merit:

 

The award “SURFing the Interface between Chemistry and Biology” allowed 30 undergraduate students to experience a 10-week summer research program at The Scripps Research Institute (TSRI) in Jupiter, Florida, an internationally renowned leader in basic and translational science. From 2014-2016 our summer program combined a high-level research experience at the bench with professional development opportunities aimed to increase the students’ preparation for graduate school, as well as the competitiveness of their application. Finally, group-building activities such as a trip to Disney World, a nighttime excursion to watch nesting sea turtles, are used to build a cohort-experience.

The types of scientific projects that summer undergraduates carried out vary widely, depending on the host laboratory, ranging from Neuroscience, over Immunology to Biochemistry, Structural Biology to Chemistry. In the last three years 28 labs have participated in our summer undergraduate programs, but all projects reflect the interdisciplinary thematic focus of research at the interface between chemistry and different areas of biology, which is a hallmark of TSRI. All students had independent projects, carried out under the direct supervision of a senior graduate student or postdoc, with the active involvement of the faculty mentor. Thus, the students had a realistic experience of the way that graduate research is conducted: independently, under the guide of a faculty mentor, and, typically growing from the project of a more senior lab member. Projects were designed to reflect the limited time and experience the students can bring to the project.

In addition to measuring student learning in self-reported surveys, we have tracked the students’ success and career choices. Of the students that have already graduated, 67% are now enrolled in Ph.D. programs in the biomedical or chemical sciences, many in the top schools around the country, including UCSF, Stanford, Yale, and Johns Hopkins, 13% are working as a research technician with plans for graduate school. The remaining students are pursuing careers in medicine, outside of science, or are unknown.

An additional measure of success in the research training goals are products, such as conference presentations, fellowships and publications co-authored by our students. 14 students have presented their work at national meetings, such as the ACS, ASBMB, ASCB, RNA society, Cold Spring Harbor and Keystone meetings, as well as ABRCMS and NSF meetings. Four of them won prizes at these meetings. Furthermore, two of our previous summer interns won NSF GRFP fellowships. Finally, six peer-reviewed publications were co-authored by our summer interns.

 

Broader Impacts:

 

South Florida does not have a large number of research-intensive academic institutions. As a result, local students at all levels of education often find a limited number of role models for careers in science. The lack of role models and opportunities is even more of a concern for students from underserved communities. South Florida and the Southeastern United States are home to large populations of students underrepresented in the STEM fields, including Hispanic and African American students. Additionally, these areas also have large disparities in income and educational opportunities, which can limit the opportunities for low-income students of all ethnic backgrounds, who are often the first of their families to attend college.

We have targeted our recruitment efforts at these demographies (first-generation college students, racial minorities) to provide these neediest students with a meaningful research and career-development experience, which will strengthen not just their career prospects, but also substantially enhance the National STEM pipeline. In 2015 and 2016 we have had 90 and 80% participation of racial minorities or first-generation college students. 4 students were recruited locally, and a third of the students came from the Southeastern US. Our data indicate that our participants persist in and are successful in science. 

This summer educational program at The Scripps Research Institute in Jupiter, Florida, is part of a larger educational outreach effort directed by Dr. Rosie Albarran-Zeckler, the co-director of this grant, which has been recognized by the Florida Department of Education, Florida Board of Governors, and the Florida State House of Representatives committee on STEM education. This program includes: (i) a summer program for local high school students funded partially by the Kenan Trust; (ii) a small undergraduate summer program (~2 students annually) for High School program alumni funded by the Kenan Trust; (iii) NSF-funded professional development workshops for science teachers; (iv) A Lending Library program, which allows teachers to borrow equipment to bring experiments into their classroom. (v) Hands-on lesson plans such as What Makes You ‘You’- DNA Isolation, Drug Discovery, Model Organisms, Introduction to Science, The Basic You - An Introduction to Genetics, and Discovering the Brain and its Functions and (vi) a yearly public Science Education Day “CELLebrate Science” at a local mall, funded partially by the Berlin Family Foundation and the Gardens Mall. Collectively, these programs have provided our faculty with mentoring experience, and reached thousands of children.
